Bayesian dynamic borrowing Power likelihood (Lin et al., 2024) P ✓ ✓ Bayesian credible interval Medium Easy Requires full parameterization of data distribution and correct HTE specification
Test-then-pool Elastic integration (Yang et al., 2023) NP ✓ Asymptotics/ bootstrap Package ready Hard Requires correct HTE specification
ESCV-TMLE (Dang et al., 2023c) SP ✓ ✓ Asymptotics Package ready Hard Interpretability is challenging
Weighted combination Anchored thresholding (Chen et al., 2021) NP Bootstrap Easy Easy No reversion to RCT-only with increasing bias
MSE-minimizing (Oberst et al., 2022) NP ✓ Bootstrap Easy Easy
Bias correction Experiment grounding (Kallus et al., 2018) SP ✓ bootstrap Easy Hard Assumes linearity; Efficiency gains in HTE but not in ATE estimation
Confounding function (Yang et al., 2020) SP ✓ Asymptotics/ bootstrap Package ready Hard Requires correct HTE specification; Efficiency gains in HTE but not in ATE estimation
Covariate adjustment PROCOVA (Schuler et al., 2021) P ✓ Sandwich estimator Easy Easy Limited efficiency gain when outcome is nearly linear
Shrinkage Green et al. (2005) NP ✓ Bootstrap Easy Easy Requires multiple independent strata estimates
Rosenman et al. (2023a) NP ✓ Bootstrap Easy Easy Requires multiple independent strata estimates

references: Table 1 provides a practical summary of the methods discussed above, serving as a reference for researchers selecting an appropriate method. The “data assumption” column indicates whether a method is parametric (P), non-parametric (NP) or semi-parametric (SP). Understanding these assumptions helps users recognize their limitations: semi-parametric methods require correct model specification of the parametric part to avoid biased estimates, while non-parametric methods offer flexibility but may have poor finite sample performance. The next two columns indicate whether a method is applicable to combining only the control arm or both arms from the RWD. The “inference” column describes how each approach quantifies uncertainty. The following column assesses the difficulty of implementation, specifically coding difficulty. “Easy” denotes straightforward coding in a couple of lines, while methods like the power likelihood approach are marked as “medium” due to the need for users to specify a causal model and assemble basic functions despite the available package. The R packages available are: causl (Evans, 2021) and ManyData (Lin, 2023) for the power likelihood approach, ElasticIntegrative(Yang and Gao, 2023) for the elastic integrative estimator, EScvtmle (Dang et al., 2023b) for the ESCV-TMLE estimator, and IntegrativeHTEcf (Yang, 2020) for the confounding function method. See Appendix A for details. The “alternative estimands” column compares the complexity of adapting methods to estimands such as relative risk. Semi-parametric methods typically require significant modification, such as replacing the efficient influence function, and current packages often lack this flexibility. The final column lists primary limitations for users to consider.

Table 1 outlines practical considerations when choosing a data fusion method. Figure 11 provides a guide for selecting a method based on specific research needs. A key initial consideration is the availability of treated subjects in RWD and whether to include them in the fusion. This is crucial when new treatments or policies are not yet available in the real world. If no unit received treatment in the RWD, the methods to consider are power likelihood (Lin et al., 2024), ESCV-TMLE (Dang et al., 2023c) and PROCOVA (Schuler et al., 2021). Notably, PROCOVA provides Type 1 error protection and sample size calculation, although its power gains are often limited.

references: However, the above simulation assumes that the prognostic score is perfect, i.e. m⁢(X)=𝔼⁢[Y⁢(0)|X,S=1]𝑚𝑋𝔼delimited-[]conditional𝑌0𝑋𝑆1m(X)=\mathbb{E}[Y(0)|X,S=1]italic_m ( italic_X ) = blackboard_E [ italic_Y ( 0 ) | italic_X , italic_S = 1 ] using the notations in Schuler et al. (2021). The authors relaxed this assumption in their Theorem 2, replacing it with the condition |m⁢(X)−μ0⁢(X)|→L20subscript𝐿2→𝑚𝑋subscript𝜇0𝑋0\left|m(X)-\mu_{0}(X)\right|\xrightarrow{L_{2}}0| italic_m ( italic_X ) - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ) | start_ARROW start_OVERACCENT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_OVERACCENT → end_ARROW 0, where μ0⁢(X)≡𝔼⁢[Y⁢(0)|X,S=1]subscript𝜇0𝑋𝔼delimited-[]conditional𝑌0𝑋𝑆1\mu_{0}(X)\equiv\mathbb{E}[Y(0)|X,S=1]italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ) ≡ blackboard_E [ italic_Y ( 0 ) | italic_X , italic_S = 1 ]. To test the sensitivity to the perfect prognostic score assumption, we distinguished the curvature coefficient α𝛼\alphaitalic_α for the RCT and RWD models by αrsubscript𝛼𝑟\alpha_{r}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and αosubscript𝛼𝑜\alpha_{o}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Note that in this setting, the condition |m⁢(X)−μ0⁢(X)|→L20subscript𝐿2→𝑚𝑋subscript𝜇0𝑋0\left|m(X)-\mu_{0}(X)\right|\xrightarrow{L_{2}}0| italic_m ( italic_X ) - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ) | start_ARROW start_OVERACCENT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_OVERACCENT → end_ARROW 0 still holds. Table 2 gives the relative RMSE in different (αosubscript𝛼𝑜\alpha_{o}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT,αrsubscript𝛼𝑟\alpha_{r}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) scenarios. We observe that the most efficiency gain is generally achieved when αr=αosubscript𝛼𝑟subscript𝛼𝑜\alpha_{r}=\alpha_{o}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the benefit diminishes when there is a discrepancy. Interestingly, when the RCT outcome is quadratic w.r.t. X4subscript𝑋4X_{4}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT but the RWD is linear without X4subscript𝑋4X_{4}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the RMSE of the PROCOVA estimator is even higher than τ^rsubscript^𝜏𝑟\hat{\tau}_{r}over^ start_ARG italic_τ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In this case, the prognostic score introduces more noise than it explains in Y𝑌Yitalic_Y’s residual variation. Essentially, in a most simplified multivariate regression scenario, the variance of the regression coefficient of the treatment A𝐴Aitalic_A can be expressed as:
